claim_cards.claim: A metric-agnostic coherence-current is proposed: because d∘d≡0, the derived current is closed (dJ=0), giving a topological conservation law independent of any chosen metric.
claim_cards.test_hook: Implement the current definition in a toy model; verify dJ=0 holds under metric changes and coordinate re-parameterizations.
claim_cards.evidence_excerpt: the current is trivially closed: dJΦ = 0 ... independent of any chosen metric

claim_cards.claim: The ‘recursive isochrone’ Σ is defined as the zero-locus J′=0 cutting out a co-dimension-1 submanifold; trajectories confined to Σ satisfy the Φ-Bridge equality without invoking background spacetime.
claim_cards.test_hook: Construct Σ explicitly in a low-dimensional surrogate system; test whether restricting dynamics to Σ enforces the stated equality conditions.
claim_cards.evidence_excerpt: The zero locus J' = 0 cuts out ... Σ ... without referencing a background spacetime.

claim_cards.claim: The metric is framed as secondary: defining u_B≔∂_BΦ and requiring divergence-free flow (θ=0) is claimed to reproduce the Einstein field equation G_BC = 8π Φ_BC as an effective relation on Σ.
claim_cards.test_hook: Translate the construction into a calculable setting; test whether θ=0 implies an Einstein-like relation under the paper’s definitions.
claim_cards.evidence_excerpt: Requiring a divergence-free flow (θ = 0) reproduces the Einstein field equation

claim_cards.claim: Horizon formation is characterized by saturation of coherence flux (E'_F=0); information is claimed to be phase-locked at Σ, bypassing the information-loss paradox without requiring global time.
claim_cards.test_hook: Operationalize a ‘flux saturation’ condition in an analogue system and test whether it correlates with any measurable ‘locking’ behavior.
claim_cards.evidence_excerpt: horizon formation ... saturation of coherence flux ... Information never falls into a geometry; it is phase-locked at Σ.

claim_cards.claim: Black holes are reframed as recursive coherence sinks/regulators; Hawking temperature is interpreted as residual coherence flux escaping due to finite recursive delay (not thermal randomness).
claim_cards.test_hook: Map the proposed ‘recursive delay’ interpretation to a quantitative model; check whether it reproduces standard scaling relations while yielding new falsifiable signatures.
claim_cards.evidence_excerpt: Hawking temperature ... residual coherence flux escaping due to finite recursive delay

claim_cards.claim: Large-scale cosmic structure (filaments/voids/attractors) is attributed to ‘gravitational turbulence’ producing recursive phase networks; Φ is asserted to regulate the balance between curvature and expansion across scales.
claim_cards.test_hook: Define measurable proxies for ‘phase network’ and the stated balance; test against cosmological simulation outputs for discriminating predictions.
claim_cards.evidence_excerpt: Cosmic webs thus form as recursive phase networks ... Φ regulates the balance between curvature ... and expansion

claim_cards.claim: Operational protocols are provided to estimate the Φ-invariant from finite-resolution data in three test-beds (turbulence, Bose gases, superconducting qubits), producing a Φ(t) trace whose plateau duration Δτ and height Φ* are framed as direct falsifiers.
claim_cards.test_hook: Implement all three protocols on at least one dataset each; report Φ(t), Δτ, Φ* and whether a plateau exists under stated preprocessing.
claim_cards.evidence_excerpt: All protocols output a Φ-trace ... plateau duration Δτ and height Φ⋆ are direct falsifiers

claim_cards.claim: A universal preprocessing recipe is specified: acquire field snapshots, band-pass to an inertial/coherence range using k-IR and k-UV bounds, then compute local gradient amplitude Δ(x,t)=||∇F|| and its spatial mean Δ̄(t).
claim_cards.test_hook: Run the preprocessing exactly as written; verify Δ̄(t) stability under small changes to band-pass bounds and resolution η.
claim_cards.evidence_excerpt: Band-pass ... Compute local gradient amplitude Δ(x,t)=∥∇F∥ and its spatial mean

claim_cards.claim: For classical turbulence, Φ(t) is defined as Φ(t)=Ṡ / (Q̇/T), with Ṡ(t_k)=(2ν/Δ̄)⟨ω^2⟩ and Q̇(t)=ε(t) from third-order structure functions, with T≡⟨v^2⟩/3.
claim_cards.test_hook: Compute Φ(t) on an open DNS dataset; verify numerical stability and compare Φ(t) behavior across Reynolds number and filtering choices.
claim_cards.evidence_excerpt: Entropy production rate ... Dissipative flux ... Φ(t) = Ṡ / (Q̇/T)

claim_cards.claim: An expected turbulence plateau is asserted: Φ* ≈ 0.42 ± 0.03 for Re_λ ≳ 250.
claim_cards.test_hook: Evaluate Φ* across multiple Re_λ DNS datasets; test whether the plateau value and variance match the stated range.

claim_cards.claim: A continuity condition (‘Φ-Bridge’) is proposed linking quantum and gravitational regimes via equality of their coherence fluxes; when it holds, the system lies on a recursive isochrone where micro and macro coherence evolve at the same normalized rate.
claim_cards.test_hook: Specify operational definitions of the two fluxes in an analogue platform (e.g., BEC horizon); test whether the equality condition corresponds to an identifiable plateau regime.
claim_cards.evidence_excerpt: RGPx postulates a single continuity condition — the Φ-Bridge — linking these domains

claim_cards.claim: The quantum–gravitational coupling is defined by a recursive exchange term J_Φ that measures bidirectional coherence current between the two domains.
claim_cards.test_hook: Derive J_Φ in a concrete field model; test whether J_Φ→0 corresponds to measurable ‘phase-locking’ signatures.
claim_cards.evidence_excerpt: Their coupling is defined by the recursive exchange term

claim_cards.claim: A unified differential invariant is asserted: ∇·Φ = 0, framed as global conservation of coherence flux analogous to energy-momentum continuity.
claim_cards.test_hook: Check whether the invariant is well-defined under the paper’s field definitions; test its conservation numerically in at least one simulated system.
claim_cards.evidence_excerpt: Both regimes satisfy the same differential invariant
